review_title: Great Benefits, Great Job, Depends on Environment
pros: Great benefits, competitive pay, opportunities for growth, free coffee, option to transfer easily, tuition reimbursement through Arizona State University, GREAT job if you love coffee.
cons: If management is not great, you will suffer. If the environment you are in as a store is not great, you will suffer. This is a very fast-paced (fast food, truly) job that is just trying to get the “best” quality goods out to the public as quickly as possible. You are always reminded of how replaceable you are, but it is also very hard to get fired from Starbucks for anything less than full-on blasphemy. It is corporate to a fault, but you can use this job to your advantage and enjoy it if you don’t let the cons get to you.

review_title: Great job while going to school
pros: I had the privilege to work with some of the greatest people that are still friends two years after moving on. The atmosphere was friendly and supportive and it was great to be able to qualify for health insurance while working part-time. If you stay on top of your schedule and put in your days needed off well in advance and keep open communication with your managers then it's a great experience.
cons: You are as happy or unhappy as you want to be, but in retail compartmentalizing is a necessity. Not all customers are happy nor coworkers. Some shifts are more demanding than others and can throw off your sleep schedule. As well, with the muscle memory needed for a daily assortment of routine tasks there are bound to be some aches and pains to follow. If your preferred work station and schedule availability are not self advocated and communicated regularly, it's likely that they can be derailed or exhausted without boundaries set in place.

pros: I loved most of my coworkers and the relationships I made with our regulars. Feeling like you can make someone’s entire day by giving them a compliment or telling them you believe in them is rewarding.
cons: The pay does not match the expectations whatsoever. I felt I was putting out fires more than my store manager. There is a major disconnect here. My store manager would expect me to stay late to cover for people who informed him in advance that they wouldn’t be coming in. The pay rate is different for a reason however my store manager felt working on the floor was beneath him. The baristas hated working with him because they felt uncomfortable around him. Numerous people left because they felt undervalued & underpaid. Ontop of this, if other baristas choose not to work hard it causes others to have to work 10xs harder to make up for their lack of work ethic. I would bring these situations to my store managers attention & nothing would be done. There could be a documentary on drama within Starbucks stores it is that bad. Nothing is resolved for that would require confrontation & a level of accountability. Due to staffing issues, the store manager will turn a blind eye or sweep things under the rug to avoid losing people.

pros:

cons:
Though the company strives towards equality and acceptance for all, being white, make, straight, and Christian is very hard to feel part of the family and feel as the company appreciates and values your hard work. 
I am fortunate as I was grandfathered in at a time when the value of the human Spirit was for everyone, not just minorities, gays, lesbians, and transgenders. 

(Don’t mistake this for hate either, because I love and get along with each and everyone of my team members. I’ve just seen other round and immature partners not yet mature enough to learn how to adapt, accept, and appreciate others outside their views without offending others).

review_title: Good for a part time job
pros: Good as a part time job. Healthcare is accessible. At it's core, it is a really fun job. You meet cool people from all over the world. The discount is very generous. Opportunities to ASU. Pay is higher than average for the same work in the area.
cons: If you make it your full time job and intend to stick around a while, you will eventually get a bad manager and life will be miserable. There are not high requirements for managers and thus, you get a lot of terrible leadership making a fun job draining. Starbucks regulations are too lax on reprimanding, and if you take your job seriously you are the odd one out. Corporate constantly pushes new initiatives (pastry case rehauls, 9-step Frappuccino's, etc.) without the required training hours for said initiatives to go smoothly. Of course, corporate isn't getting screamed at for these terrible ideas in storefronts so it's easy for them not to care that it sucked.

review_title: You have to take care of yourself
pros: Some of the best friends I have had in my life are because of this company. You have the ability to change your career, but you have to do it yourself. Promotions don't happen unless you know someone and are on the inside track. Company is diverse in many areas, which is great.
cons: Weak management that is not trained in the areas of soft skills. Very obvious favoritism all around and if you are not "in" don't expect to get good raises, bonuses or stock. Passive aggressive and leaders would rather wait for a layoff to deal with underperformers than have the constructive, courageous conversations. If you thing you are cruising along, keep asking, because it may just come back to surprise you.

review_title: Not as progressive and accommodating as they pretend to be
pros: Amazing benefits but you will sacrifice your physical and mental health for a practically unlivable wage.
cons: Extremely high stress, scrupulous thankless work, unshakeable adherence to standards, managers press for workers to be more competitive without any achievable rewards. No one accommodates for disabilities. Sexist environment, disrespectful and condescending towards those of non-binary or transgender identities. They did not invest time into training me properly and wrote me up for minor misdemeanors that were completely preventable if they allowed me to decompress after handling abusive customers. Despite them claiming that I was a strong partner who made great strides and improvements, they fired me over a complete misunderstanding that I had already been coached on previously in the moment. They lacked sympathy for me as someone who had within my time employed, went through two baker acts, coping dropping out of college, a pandemic, working two jobs, going through a six month relationship that ended in a break up, two car accidents (one was my fault the other caused by a customer while I was working a shift at my second job), an Autism diagnosis, my father having cancer and much much more. They did not understand my responses to workplace trauma and their only solution was to use Lyra. Which I did. And the psychologist denied the validity of my Autism diagnosis that I received from a legitimate psychiatrist.

pros: The only pros were the people and the benefits(if you could get them).
cons: Not enough pay. You will make 50-120 drinks per hour costing anywhere from 5-12 but make around 10 and hour. Everyone always brings up how good the benefits are but that's only if you can get full time. For where I live if you wanted full time you would have to work around 2-3 stores to get enough hours. The business is run very differently in the south vs the north. During the pandemic company policies were not followed through due to coworkers/management's personal beliefs. Overall my biggest issue is the business model of being the friendliest baristas at the expense of the workers well being. Often if a customer was upset and berated the employees they were rewarded with a gift card or a free drink.

pros: Starbucks offers great benefits, salary, and bonuses if you meet specific sales quota. It’s a great place to work if you are young and starting out in the workforce.
cons: You are expected to be on call 24/7. They demand results. They constantly ask what they can do to help managers but seldom do they implement anything managers ask. This would be a great place to work if you don’t have family/kids, or you are trying to build your career. Working at Starbucks as upper management looks awesome on your resume but is incredibly demanding. Average a minimum of 50 hours a week on a good week. Expectations are high and you will learn a lot and grow. Not for the faint of heart. Need thick skin now a days to be in retail.

job_title: Barista/Shift Supervisor in Hales Corners, WI
pros: -Benefits for both full and part time employees (if you use them)
cons:
Let me start off by saying that each individuals experience from store to store may vary. When I first started, I was having a great time, I always wanted to be a barista. Eventually I got promoted to a supervisor, which was fine and dandy for a while. 
My store has gone through 5 managers in my 2 (almost 3 years) of being here. Eventually this job will cause burnout. Ever since the pandemic started, it's been nonstop busy, people are quitting like crazy, stores are closing, and we have insane shortages. Because of this, customers have become vile, even more entitled, and waaay meaner than usual.
Our one good manager (manager #4) left, which is good for her, and we have a younger, less experienced manager. He's trying his best, I think, but I am getting to the point where I feel like I'm going crazy. Coaching your partners is one thing, but blatantly telling them that you're going to write them up for not taking their lunch early enough is too much. Especially when you're never on the floor helping your team when they clearly could use an extra set of hands. I would say that the shift supervisors and the baristas are the backbone of this store and if you treat them poorly, you'll just drive everyone away. 

We're all just tired and trying our best. I wish upper management would see that and not just how fast we could get a customer in and out of the drive thru or how much we "connect" with customers who don't even acknowledge that we are human.

If you plan on working for this company, please make sure you have a good manager and a good store.

review_title: Fun job with the right team
pros:
Lots of benefits, including free drinks and a food mark out during your shift.

Shifts usually go by fast when you’re busy.

Fun coworkers make working in retail bearable.

Tips are available every week.

Once you get the hang of making drinks and other parts of the job, the job is actually pretty easy. It only gets difficult when it gets extremely busy or when understaffed.
cons:
It’s a retail job, so expect difficult customers. Most customers are polite and considerate, but there will always be the ones that act entitled, rude, and demanding. 
(Especially with customers that have very specific/complicated drink orders, or customers that find recipes online).

If management is lacking, expect being understaffed and overworked. 

A lot can be expected out of you, such as making “connections” with customers, and going above and beyond to make customers’ day. Sometimes it happens, but in reality, we’re just trying to get drinks out.

pros: Plenty of opportunities to pick up shifts or change them for your own store or another. Really great wrap around benefits. Generally managerial staff for my specific store had good leadership and were accommodating. Small little rewards like taking home some whole bean coffee products, the company drink/meal, and things like that. A decent part time job or full time depending on your store location.
cons: I worked on the 34 Street Macy's Starbucks so I feel like my experience wasn't what the typical store would be. Everyday we had a rush of customers and had to deal with a lot of language barriers due to all the tourists. The training I received was adequate which made the job bearable, however no amount of training could prepare you for the volume of customers that visit Starbucks on the regular and the entitlement of some. While there were plenty of opportunities to pick up or change shifts, which made it easier to make money, the output of work in comparison to the checks wasn't worth the daily exhaustion that would seep into the next shift.

pros: Awesome benefits, fun coworkers, decent pay, positive working environment
cons:
The amount of time it takes to handcraft each drink does not coincide with the times they want us to finish. Add the fact that customers can make any combination of drinks that they want (which also increases how quickly we make our drinks), corporate doesn’t seem to understand that we can’t make drinks in mere seconds or minutes. 

There’s also the unrealistic expectation of making “customer connections” that I feel corporate doesn’t seem to understand why getting high connection scores are an issue. Not everyone getting a coffee wants to chat about their weekend plans or something. Some people just want to get their coffees and go!

pros:
For a simple retail/customer service job, Starbucks really does look out for its employees. They have great benefits like health care, dental care, free classes at Arizona State University, and more.

Just to put into perspective how much the company really cares for its employees, during the start of the pandemic, when so many people were getting fired and laid off from their jobs, Starbucks gave us the option to keep working during the pandemic. If we decided to no go into work, Starbucks still paid us on a weekly basis for a little over a month. It's rare to see a company this large look out for every one of its employees lie the way they have.
cons: I don't really have any cons. You'll either have a good experience or bad experience in this company based on the team you have in your store. If you have good management and good coworkers, you'll overall have a good experience and vice versa

review_title: Fun Work Environment, Mentally and Physically Exhausting
pros:
- Competitive Benefits
- Free coffee, food and generous discount
- Diverse co-workers
- Manager are usually very friendly
-Good hours
cons:
- Constant changes to management, standards and procedures making it hard to keep adapting
- It feels like the company has slowly shifted towards micromanaging their staff because of their losses from COVID by pushing sales and numbers more than creating customer connections.
- Sometimes the customers can be very rude and degrading towards the baristas for small mistakes.
- In my situation, part time meant between 25-30 hours a week but they spread it out five days a week making it feel like full time.
